issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: In modal's I've checked, there is no initial field focus. You'd expect it to be in the first field of the dialog, or at least in the dialog somewhere!
fields.summary: initial focus not on first field in most modals

comments.body: Yes, everything should have initial focus (generally in the first field, or widget). This is a regression.

The setFocus implementation in pull request 276 did not handle dialogs that have neither an input field nor a button, so a subsequent pull request (https://github.com/eucalyptus/koala/pull/299) was required to fix this issue without breaking dialogs such as the "About your cloud" modal.

* i am not seeing the visible focus when it's on a button even when it appears to be there since the spacebar activates the button (like on stop instance for example)
* on dialogs where the initial focus is on the close button (like for a destructive action like terminate instance), spacebar is not activating the widget in focus like it should

verification done on mac osx 10.9.2, FF 27.0.1
[~kyolee] AFAICT adding a :focus pseudo-selector to the CSS should fix this.  Going to take a stab at it--reassigned to me for now.
[~jloza] If the focused element isn't highlighted on Firefox per se, we should open a new ticket for that IMO and move this one along.  Thoughts?

[~kgill] yes we can do that as long as the focus is defined for all the pages. If that's the case and you are otherwise flummoxed at his point, assign this to me to review and I'll move it along and open a new ticket.
[~jloza] Agreed we should open a new ticket for the Firefox-specific focus issue.

I opened GUI-749 for the focus indicator visibility on FF issue, but also the other thing I mentioned originally is not working on chrome either. 

"on dialogs where the initial focus is on the close button (like for a destructive action like terminate instance), spacebar is not activating the widget in focus like it should"

Spacebar should activate any focused button, including close buttons.

[~jloza] The spacebar-activating-focus behavior is browser-specific, so there's not much we can do nudge Chrome in the right direction here.  

Honestly, I'm surprised (and somewhat nervous) to discover that pressing the spacebar would submit the form in the dialog when the button has focus.  I would have guessed that only the Enter key press would cause the submit, not the spacebar.  Just my 2 cents.

[~kgill] spacebar activating a button in focus is *extremely* standard behavior, since the dawn of software time...

In a future release we will work on full accessibility (It's not an official requirement right now but will become one if we ever have an opportunity to get Euca into the federal government for example, but if I see things like this that break it I file bugs anyway) and then I will teach you all kinds of new things that you never imagined! :)

[~jloza] Tried changing the close "x" in a dialog from an a tag to a button element, and the spacebar refuses to activate the close (tested across a few browsers).  Pressing the enter key, however, does close the dialog.

Suggesting we move this one to QA, as the initial focus is properly set in the dialogs and appears to be activated by pressing the enter key.  We should open a new ticket for activating the focused item via spacebar-keypress for Section 508 compliance, since that's potentially going to require a significant amount of work.

@kamal i opened a bug for the spacebar thing, that is not 4.0 critical (which I mentioned in the bug as well). Just FYI Enter key should not be activating a button in focus, that is reserved for the default button (I'll do a lesson on this stuff for the team later, maybe at 4.1 summit so we can start thinking about that stuff as we build dialogs and build it in)...the ESC key should activate the close button in addition to the default button as well. It's a lot to know. Thanks! Moving this one to QA.

[~jloza] ok thanks.  BTW, the ESC key closes the modals per Foundation's default behavior.  For the Enter key press activating a button in focus, nothing in our code has wired that up so it's either a Foundation behavior or one built into the browser.

focus is there, but it's useless since tab does not move focus around the dialog. Separate ticket opened for that, to be implemented in a future release. 

Verified on mac osx 10.9.2, FF 28.0
